# References {.unnumbered}

A collection of useful resources and tools.

### Concepts

#### Explainability

- [Interpretable Machine Learning](https://christophm.github.io/interpretable-ml-book/): A practical overview of techniques for making ML models more transparent, including SHAP, LIME, and model-specific tools.
- [SHAP Documentation](https://shap.readthedocs.io/en/latest/): Official docs for SHAP (SHapley Additive exPlanations), a method to interpret the output of machine learning models.

#### Visualization

- [UW Interactive Data Lab Curriculum](https://idl.uw.edu/visualization-curriculum/intro.html): Visualization using Vega-Lite and Altair.
- [Fundamentals of Data Visualization](https://clauswilke.com/dataviz/): Principles and examples of clear, effective visual communication.

#### Time Series

- [Forecasting: Principles and Practice](https://otexts.com/fpp2/): Covers forecasting techniques like exponential smoothing and ARIMA, with examples in R.

#### Data Imputation

- [Flexible Imputation of Missing Data](https://stefvanbuuren.name/fimd/): Methods to handle missing data, with emphasis on multiple imputation.

#### Fraud Detection

- [Fraud Detection Handbook](https://fraud-detection-handbook.github.io/fraud-detection-handbook/Foreword.html): Applied techniques for detecting fraud in highly imbalanced, real-world datasets. Includes examples and code.



### Tools
- [SDV](https://github.com/sdv-dev/SDV) - Python library for creating tabular synthetic data.

### Resources used to make this guide

- [Quarto](https://quarto.org/): Publishing system. Supports notebooks, markdown, citations, and publishing to HTML and PDF.
- [bootswatch](https://bootswatch.com/): Collection of free themes for Bootstrap-based sites (used to style this book).
